text: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a developmental disability caused by differences in the brain. People with ASD often have problems with social communication and interaction, and restricted or repetitive behaviors or interests.
Signs of autism usually appear by age 2 or 3. Some associated development delays can appear even earlier, and often, it can be diagnosed as early as 18 months.

While there is no one known cause of autism, early intervention can improve outcomes. Some of the increased risk factors include having a sibling with ASD, having older parents, and certain genetic conditions.
Autism is a 'spectrum' disorder because there is wide variation in the type and severity of symptoms people experience.
People with ASD may have difficulty with social communication and interaction, restricted interests, and repetitive behaviors.
There is no medical test for autism. Doctors look at the child's developmental history and behavior to make a diagnosis.
Early intervention services help children from birth to 3 years old (36 months) learn important skills. Services can include therapy to help the child talk, walk, and interact with others.
Many people with autism have sensory issues. These typically involve over- or under-sensitivities to sounds, lights, touch, tastes, smells, pain and other stimuli.
Autism is a lifelong condition, but many children diagnosed with ASD go on to live independent, productive, and fulfilling lives.
Every person with autism is unique, with their own strengths and challenges. Some people with ASD may require significant support in their daily lives, while others may need less support.

Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) is one of the most widely used therapy approaches for people with autism. It encourages positive behaviors and discourages negative ones to improve a variety of skills.
Many autistic adults advocate for acceptance and understanding, rather than a cure. They see autism as a different way of thinking and perceiving the world.
Research suggests that autism develops from a combination of genetic and nongenetic, or environmental, influences. These influences appear to increase the risk that a child will develop autism.

Some common signs of autism in young children include not responding to their name, avoiding eye contact, not smiling when you smile at them, getting very upset if they do not like a certain taste, smell or sound.
While there is no cure for autism, there are several interventions that can help individuals with ASD. These may include behavioral treatments, medicines or both.
Many people with autism have co-occurring conditions, such as epilepsy, depression, anxiety, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
Autism affects all ethnic and socioeconomic groups. Minority groups tend to be diagnosed later and less often.
Some autistic people may need little or no support. Others may need help from a parent or carer every day.

Adults with autism may face challenges in areas such as social interaction, employment, and living independently. However, many lead fulfilling lives and make significant contributions to their communities.
Early signs of autism can include delayed speech development, not babbling or pointing by age 1, not responding to their name, and loss of previously acquired speech or social skills.
